question_text:

$$ r = \frac{2GM}{c^2} $$

A student carries out an experiment to investigate how irradiance of light varies with distance.

A small lamp is placed at a distance \( d \) from a light meter. The irradiance \( I \) at this distance is displayed on the light meter. This measurement is repeated for a range of different distances.

The student uses these results to plot the graph shown.

{{IMAGE}}
The graph indicates that there is a systematic uncertainty in the experiment.

Which of the following alterations would be most likely to reduce the systematic uncertainty in this experiment?
option_a: Repeating the experiment in a darkened room
option_b: Repeating the readings at each distance and calculating averages
option_c: Decreasing the brightness of the lamp
option_d: Replacing the small lamp with a larger lamp

question_text:

[s]I Coherent waves have a constant phase relationship.
II Coherent waves have the same frequency.
III Coherent waves have the same speed.[/s]
Which of the statements is/are correct?
Dark lines in an absorption spectrum occur because
option_a: photons move from higher to lower energy levels emitting electrons
option_b: photons move from lower to higher energy levels by absorbing electrons
option_c: electrons move from lower to higher energy levels emitting photons
option_d: electrons move from higher to lower energy levels emitting photons
option_e: electrons move from lower to higher energy levels by absorbing photons

option_c: decreases its conductivity by allowing more electrons to reach the conduction band

I The peak wavelength of emitted radiation is longer for hotter objects than for cooler objects.
II A 'blue' star is likely to be hotter than a 'red' star.

The total mass of the particles after the reaction is 8.317 × 10⁻²⁷ kg.

A student makes the following statements about wave particle duality.
[s]
I The photoelectric effect is evidence supporting the particle model of light.
II Interference is evidence supporting the wave model of light.
III Photons of sufficient energy can eject electrons from the surface of metals.[/s]
Which of these statements is/are correct?

Electromagnetic radiation of frequency 9.0 × 10¹⁴ Hz is incident on a clean, negatively charged metal surface.
The work function of the metal is 6.1 × 10⁻¹⁹ J.

This is explained by the fact that
option_a: photoemission can only occur from a positively charged metal surface
option_b: the wavelength of the incident radiation is too short
option_c: the frequency of the incident radiation is less than the threshold frequency of this metal
option_d: the work function of the metal is less than the energy of the incident photons
option_e: the number of photons per second incident on the surface of the metal is too low

question_text:

\( r \) is the orbital radius of the star, in m
\( G \) is the Universal Constant of Gravitation.

The total mass of a motorcycle and rider is 250 kg.
During braking they are brought to rest from a speed of 16.0 m s⁻¹ in a time of 10.0 s.

The maximum energy that could be converted to heat in the brakes is

A carpenter is building a doorframe using a nail gun. The nail gun of mass 5.0 kg fires a nail of mass 4.0 g.
The nail gun and nail are initially at rest.
The speed of the nail immediately after firing is 150 m s⁻¹.

The recoil speed of the nail gun immediately after firing is

The escape velocity \( v \) of an object is the minimum velocity required to allow the object to escape the gravitational field of a planet.
The following relationship is used to determine the escape velocity
$$ v = \sqrt{\frac{2GM}{r}} $$
where
\( G \) is the Universal Constant of Gravitation
\( M \) is the mass of the planet
\( r \) is the radius of the planet.

A planet has a mass of 4.87 x 10²⁴ kg and a radius of 6.05 x 10⁶ m.

Based on this information, the escape velocity from this planet is

A spacecraft is travelling at 6.0 x 10⁷ m s⁻¹ relative to a star.

An observer on the spacecraft measures the speed of light emitted by the star to be

A spacecraft is travelling at a speed of 0.45\( c \) relative to Earth.
An observer on Earth measures the time taken for the spacecraft to travel between two points to be 72 hours.

An observer on the spacecraft measures the time taken to travel between these two points to be

The redshift of light from a distant galaxy is 0.125.

The approximate distance to this distant galaxy is

A student makes the following statements about the Universe.[s]
I Measurements of the velocities of galaxies and their distances from us lead to the theory of the origin of the expanding Universe.
II The mass of a galaxy can be estimated by the orbital speed of stars within it.
III Evidence supporting the existence of dark matter comes from the accelerating rate of expansion of the Universe.
[/s]
Which of these statements is/are correct?
Which of the following diagrams represents the electric field between a positive point charge and a negative point charge?
The group of matter particles known as fermions consists of

A certain type of composite particle is made of two up quarks and a strange quark.

The charge on an up quark is \( +\frac{2}{3}e \).
The charge on a strange quark is \( -\frac{1}{3}e \).

Which of the following statements describes this particle?
option_a: The particle is a meson with a charge of +1e
option_b: The particle is a meson with a charge of -1e
option_c: The particle is a meson with no charge
option_d: The particle is a baryon with a charge of -1e
option_e: The particle is a baryon with a charge of +1e

question_text:
Two changes in a radioactive decay series are shown below.
[c]$$ {}_{90}^{231}\text{Th} \xrightarrow{\beta} {}_{Q}^{P}\text{Pa} \xrightarrow{\alpha} {}_{S}^{R}\text{Ac} $$[/c]A Thorium nucleus emits a beta particle and the product, a Protactinium nucleus, emits an alpha particle.

Which row in the table shows the numbers represented by P, Q, R, and S?

An experiment to demonstrate the photoelectric effect is set up as shown.
[c]{{IMAGE}}[/c]Which row in the table shows the charge on the metal plate and the type of incident radiation most likely to cause photoelectric emission?
table_headers: Charge on metal plate | Type of incident radiation

question_text:
Two identical loudspeakers are connected to a signal generator as shown.

A microphone detects a maximum of sound at position X.

The microphone is now moved from X to Y.

As the microphone is moved from X to Y, a series of maxima and minima of sound are detected.
The microphone detects the second minimum of sound at position Y.

The wavelength of sound emitted by the loudspeakers is

The rays are incident at the glass-air boundary as shown.
[c]{{IMAGE}}[/c]
The refractive index of the glass for this light is 1.50.

Which of these rays pass from the glass into the air at this boundary?

The maximum voltage which can be applied across the resistor without exceeding its power rating is

One farad is equivalent to

A circuit containing a capacitor is set up as shown.
[c]{{IMAGE}}[/c]
The battery has negligible internal resistance.

The maximum charge stored by the capacitor is

A circuit is set up as shown.
[c]{{IMAGE}}[/c]
Capacitor C is initially uncharged.

Switch S is closed and the time taken for the capacitor to fully charge is recorded.
The switch is now opened and the capacitor is discharged.

Resistor R is replaced by a resistor of greater resistance.
The switch is again closed and the capacitor charges.

Which row in the table shows the effect of this change, if any, on the time taken to fully charge the capacitor and the maximum energy stored in the capacitor?
table_headers: Time taken to fully charge the capacitor | Maximum energy stored in the capacitor
